newsitem.title: DUBAI: GCC drafts rules on bank branches in member states.
newsitem.headline: GCC drafts rules on bank branches in member states.

text.p: A Gulf Cooperation Council committee has drafted a set of rules to allow regional banks to open branches in the six member states, the GCC said in a statement received on Wednesday.
The GCC's central banks and financial institutions committee met in the Saudi capital Riyadh on Sunday and Monday.
"The committee agreed on a draft for control measures to permit national banks of GCC states to open branches in member states," the council said.

The GCC -- Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Oman and Bahrain -- is a political and economic alliance. It is working to unify economic and monetary policies as part of a plan to set up a regional market.
The GCC has also been discussing a plan to link commercial bank automated teller (ATM) machines.

Individual banks within some GCC states have linked their ATM machines, and some banks offer ATM services at their foreign branches. But as yet there is no Gulf-wide system permitting customers to access their own accounts at any ATM.
